importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage by CSIRO scientists took place in late 2022, marking the start of the discovery of new deep-sea species in the Gascoyne Marine Park.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The discovery of new species occurred over a period spanning from 2022 to 2025, highlighting ongoing scientific efforts to catalog marine biodiversity.

keyTakeAways: Australia has discovered two new deep-sea species: a semi-transparent porcelain crab the size of an almond and a tiny glowing lantern shark.
The West Australian Lantern Shark is up to 40cm long, bioluminescent, and found at depths exceeding 600 meters.
The porcelain crab is about 1.5cm long and feeds using hairs instead of claws, making it a unique filter feeder.
The discoveries were made during a 2022 research voyage in the Gascoyne Marine Park, 20km off Western Australia.
Australia is a global biodiversity hotspot with over a million species, many of which remain unexplored due to deep-sea inaccessibility.
At least 20 new species have been identified from the expedition, with an estimated 600 more yet to be described and formally named due to lengthy verification processes.
Scientists from CSIRO and the Western Australian Museum are leading the research and classification efforts.

namedEntities.name: Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country known for its rich biodiversity and deep-sea exploration efforts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Australia is a global biodiversity hotspot, hosting over a million species, many of which are unique and found nowhere else.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency that conducted deep-sea research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO led the 2022 deep-sea research expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park, resulting in the discovery of new species.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The deep-sea exploration took place within this marine park, where many previously unknown species were discovered.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly described deep-sea shark species found at over 600m depth.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This bioluminescent shark is one of the two new species discovered and highlights the unique adaptations of deep-sea life.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain Crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new type of porcelain crab discovered, about 1.5cm in size and feeding with hairs instead of claws.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crab is a filter feeder, feeding on plankton using modified mouthparts, representing a unique feeding behavior among crabs.

namedEntities.name: Dr Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist from CSIRO who provided expert commentary on the lantern shark.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr White explained the bioluminescent nature of the lantern shark, contributing scientific context to the discovery.

namedEntities.name: Dr Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Curator of aquatic zoology at the Western Australian Museum who commented on the porcelain crab.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr Hosie provided insight into the unique feeding mechanism of the porcelain crab, enhancing scientific understanding.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new species of octopus found during the expedition, approximately 4cm in size and rusty red in color.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is one of the 20 new species discovered, showing the broader range of biodiversity uncovered in the deep sea.

namedEntities.name: Western Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in Australia where the research took place.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The deep-sea research was conducted off the coast of Western Australia, emphasizing regional contributions to global biodiversity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO, during a 2022 expedition to the Gascoyne Marine Park off Western Australia, discovered two new deep-sea species: a semi-transparent porcelain crab about 1.5cm in size that uses hairs to feed on plankton, and a glowing West Australian Lantern Shark up to 40cm long found at depths over 600 meters. These discoveries, part of a broader effort to explore Australia’s uncharted marine environments, highlight the country's role as a global biodiversity hotspot. So far, at least 20 species have been identified, with scientists estimating 600 more remain to be formally described due to the time required for verification. The findings underscore the importance of deep-sea exploration in expanding scientific knowledge of Earth’s unsung ecosystems.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
